indication: Coronary artery disease, heart failure, evaluate for ischemia and viability
technique: Rest and pharmacologic stress myocardial perfusion SPECT imaging was performed using Tc-99m sestamibi. Regadenoson was administered for pharmacologic stress. Gated SPECT images were obtained at rest.

protocol.stressResponse: Heart rate increased from 68 to 95 bpm. Blood pressure 142/78 at baseline, 138/72 at peak stress.
protocol.symptoms: Patient reported mild chest tightness during stress, resolved spontaneously within 2 minutes.
protocol.ecg: Baseline: Atrial fibrillation with controlled ventricular response. Stress: Non-specific ST-T changes, no diagnostic ST depression.

perfusion.stress: Moderate fixed perfusion defect involving the inferior and inferolateral walls (approximately 15% of the myocardium). Mild reversible defect in the lateral wall.
perfusion.rest: Moderate fixed perfusion defect in the inferior and inferolateral walls, unchanged from stress. The lateral wall defect shows partial reversibility.

function.wallMotion: Akinesis of the inferior wall. Hypokinesis of the inferolateral and lateral walls.

impression: Moderate fixed perfusion defect involving the inferior and inferolateral walls (approximately 15% of the myocardium), consistent with prior infarction in the RCA territory.
Mild reversible perfusion defect in the lateral wall, suggesting mild peri-infarct ischemia or hibernating myocardium.
Severely reduced left ventricular systolic function (LVEF 32%) with regional wall motion abnormalities.
No evidence of significant ischemia in other coronary territories.
recommendations: Continued optimal medical therapy for ischemic cardiomyopathy
Consider viability assessment if revascularization is being contemplated
